html: This verse depicts the trials of Jesus before the high priest, the Sanhedrin, Pilate, and Herod. Abinadi equated this verse with Jesus' submission even to an ultimate crucifixion according to the will of the Father (see Mosiah 15:6-7). That he was oppressed and afflicted is shown in the accounts of his trials (see Matt. 26:67-68; 27:29; Mark 14:65; 15:19; Luke 22:63-65). His not opening his mouth was completely fulfilled when he stood silent before Herod (see Luke 23:8-11). However, he did answer some questions put to him by Pilate (see Matt. 27:11-14) and the high priest (see Mark 14:56-62). Peter paraphrased this verse in telling of Christ's suffering (see 1 Pet. 2:23). The eunuch Philip found was reading Isaiah 53:7-8, and when Philip testified of Jesus, he was baptized (Acts 8:26-38).
